definitions.definition: to put something together with something else so as to increase the size, number, amount, etc.

examples.text: Next add the flour.
The juice contains no added sugar.
As an **added bonus**, the book includes many black-and-white photographs.
Melt the butter, then add the onion.
The plan has the added *(= extra)* advantage of bringing employment to rural areas.
Shall I add your name to the list?
They are looking at ways to **add** further **value** to their products.
There are a number of ways to **add emphasis** to words on a web page.
A new wing was added to the building.
Chlorine is added to the water to kill bacteria.

definitions.definition: to put numbers or amounts together to get a total
definitions.sensetop: add A to Badd A and B together

examples.text: He knew how to **add and subtract**.
Add 9 to the total.
If you add all these amounts together you get a huge figure.

definitions.definition: to say something more; to make a further remark
definitions.sensetop: + speechadd something to somethingadd somethingadd that…

examples.text: ‘And don't be late,’ she added.
I have nothing to add to my earlier statement.
Do you have anything to add?
He added that they would return a week later.
‘The hotel is child-friendly,’ she said, adding that special rates apply to children.

definitions.definition: to give a particular quality to an event, a situation, etc.

examples.text: The suite will add a touch of class to your bedroom.
The Easter Festival **added a** new **dimension** to Salzburg's musical life.

definitions.definition: used to introduce another fact that helps to emphasize a point you have already made

examples.text: Add to this the excellent service and you can see why it's the most popular hotel on the island.

definitions.definition: to make a bad relationship with somebody worse by offending them even more

examples.text: Then, to add insult to injury, they told me I couldn't get on the flight.
It adds insult to injury that banks are allowed to increase their charges without our knowledge or consent.
Only 300 people came to the match and, to add insult to injury, the floodlights went out during the second half.

wordOrigin: late Middle English: from Latin addere, from ad- ‘to’ + the base of dare ‘put’.
